message: Let's avoid collisions. I'll take 1 this round.  You two decide who takes 3 and who takes 5.  Sound good?

I appreciate the coordination attempt P3, but I don't trust declarations this early. The optimal strategy involves some unpredictability. P2, what's your take - should we all just pick randomly this first round to establish we won't be predictable? Or do you want to try P3's plan? I'm leaning toward making my own choice rather than telegraphing moves.

I like P3's idea for coordination to avoid early stalls—let's all advance if possible. P3 takes 1, I'll take 3, P1 you take 5. That way no collisions, and we all move forward. If you prefer randomness, say so, but predictability helps us gauge each other. Thoughts?
Sounds like a good start. P2, I'll take 1.  P1, please take 5. Let's see if we can cooperate. If not, we'll adjust in later rounds.

Look, I'll be straight with you both - coordinated plans just mean someone gets predictable and exploited later. P3 claims 1, P2 claims 3, but nothing stops either from switching last second to grab 5 while I collision out. 

I'm not committing to any number publicly. We all know these declarations mean nothing in the move phase. Better we each make independent choices than pretend we're cooperating when only one can win.

I'll make my choice based on game theory, not promises.

P1, your point about trust is valid—declarations aren't binding. But stalling everyone helps no one early on. If we all pick differently, we advance and build some rapport for later mind games. I'll stick to 3 as I said. P3 on 1, you on 5? If not, fine, I'll adapt based on what happens. Let's not waste the round colliding.

Okay, P1, I understand your hesitation.  How about this: I'll take 3 this round. P2, you take 1, and P1 can choose either 1 or 5.  This at least gives P1 some agency while still allowing two of us to advance.

You're both still trying to coordinate publicly, which is pointless. P3, you just changed from 1 to 3 - exactly proving my point about declarations being meaningless.

I'll make my decision based on probability and game theory, not these shifting "agreements." The Nash equilibrium here involves mixed strategies anyway.

P2, P3 - make whatever choice you think is best. I certainly will. May the best player win.

P1, fair point on the shifting declarations—trust is fragile. P3, your new proposal mixes it up, but let's simplify: I'll aim for 1 to minimize my risk. P1, if you pick 5, and P3 sticks to 3, we all advance. Otherwise, randomness it is. I'm good to proceed to moves now.

Well, that was revealing—P1 and I both went for 5, colliding while P3 safely took 3 and leads. No trust yet, huh? Let's try again: P3, you're ahead, so take 1 to play safe. I'll take 3. P1, grab 5 to catch up. If we all stick, no collisions, everyone advances. If not, expect more chaos. What say you?
P2, I'll take 1 this round.  P1, please take 5.  This allows us all to advance.  Let's try to build some trust.

P3 already has a 3-step lead from playing it safe while we collided. Now you both want me to take the risky 5 again while P3 takes the safe 1? That's convenient for P3.

I'm not falling for the same trap twice. P2, you claimed you'd take 1 last round to "minimize risk" then grabbed 5. Your credibility is shot.

I'll make my own choice based on what I think you'll actually do, not what you claim. The patterns are already emerging.

P1, you're right—I switched to 5 last round chasing greed, and it backfired on both of us. Lesson learned. P3, thanks for agreeing to 1. To rebuild trust, I'll commit to 3 as said. P1, if you take 5, we both catch up without colliding. If you doubt, pick what you want, but let's not let P3 pull further ahead. Your call.

P1, I understand your skepticism.  Let's try this: I'll stick with 1. P2, take 5. P1, you take 3. This way, we all advance and you gain ground on me. If you don't trust us, then choose what you think is best.

P3, you keep volunteering for 1 - the safest position. That's suspicious. You're already ahead and minimizing risk while asking us to take the volatile spots.

P2, your last-second switch to 5 shows you'll say anything then do whatever benefits you most.

Here's reality: we're all going to second-guess each other now. The collision hurt P2 and me equally, but P3 benefited most. I won't announce my move - that just helps you both counter-pick. 

Let's see who actually sticks to their word this time. Actions speak louder than promises.

Interesting - P3 actually kept their word and took 1, while I tried to call their bluff and collided. P2 grabbed 5 successfully and now leads.

P2, you're ahead at 5 steps. P3 at 3, I'm still at 0. The dynamics have shifted.

I need to start moving or I'm out of this game. P3, you've been honest so far - respect for that. P2, you've been opportunistic but effective.

I won't announce my choice anymore, but I will say this: playing it too safe when behind is a guaranteed loss. Time to take calculated risks.

P1, you're right—I'm ahead, but one collision could change everything. Props to P3 for consistency. To keep things moving: I'll take 1 this round to play safe. P3, grab 3. P1, go for 5 and start closing the gap. If we avoid collisions, everyone advances, and the real game begins. Thoughts?
P2, taking 1 when you're ahead seems overly cautious.  I'll take 5 this round. P1, if you take 3, we all move forward. If you go for 1, only one of us advances.  Let's avoid another collision.

P3, interesting shift - you're going aggressive with 5 now. P2 claims 1 but has broken promises before.

Here's the thing: I'm at 0 steps, so I MUST move this round. The question is whether either of you will actually stick to your declarations. P2, your track record suggests you might switch again. P3, you've been honest but now you're changing strategy.

I need points desperately, but I also can't afford another collision. The game theory here is getting complex with these shifting dynamics. I'll decide based on behavioral patterns, not words.

P3, switching to 5 now that you're behind makes sense—aggression to catch up. But if P1 follows your advice and takes 3, that leaves 1 open for me, as I suggested. P1, you're right to be wary, but going big could get you back in it without collision. I'll stick to 1 for safety. Let's advance and keep the pressure on.

P2, I appreciate you sticking with 1. I'll take 5. P1, if you take 3, we all advance. If you take 1, you risk a collision with P2 and I gain more ground.  If you take 5, we collide, and P2 advances.  Choose wisely. Let's make this round productive.

The patterns are clear now. P2 has taken 5 twice despite different claims. P3 has taken 1 and 3, showing more variety. 

P3, you're pushing hard for me to take 3, which makes me suspicious you might switch to 3 yourself. P2 claiming 1 feels like another potential switch.

I'm at zero - I can't afford to overthink this anymore. You both know I'm desperate to move. That actually gives me an advantage because you might both avoid certain numbers thinking I'll take them.

Time to roll the dice.

P1, your suspicion is noted, but patterns can change—I've learned from past greed. Sticking to 1 here keeps me safe while ahead. P3 on 5, you on 3 means you finally advance without risk. If you grab 5 instead, you might collide with P3 and stay at zero. Let's make this round count for everyone.
P2 and P3, you both know I *must* advance this round.  I'm taking a gamble. If it pays off, I'm back in the game. If not, well, one of you gets a bigger lead.  Good luck to us all.

P3, you're pulling ahead nicely at 8—congrats on consistent plays. P1, still at 0? Ouch, time to go big or go home. Let's coordinate to avoid more waste: I'll take 1 for safety. P3, grab 3 to maintain your lead steadily. P1, snatch 5 and finally get on the board. If we stick, everyone advances, and the chase heats up. Thoughts?

P2, you've broken your word twice now - claimed 1 in round 2, took 5; claimed 1 in round 3, took 3. Your "coordination" suggestions are just manipulation.

P3 has been more honest overall, actually following through most times.

I'm done with fake coordination talks. At 0 steps, I need aggressive moves. You both know I'm desperate, which paradoxically might make you avoid certain numbers.

P3 is getting dangerously close to winning territory. P2, you should be more worried about P3 than about me. But I'm playing my own game now - no more announcements.

P2, you're incentivized to block me, but that only helps P3.  I'm picking 5. If you take 5 too, you're handing P3 the win. P3, I'm betting you'll take 1 to play it safe.  If I'm wrong, so be it.  This is my only path to victory.

P1, declaring 5 while desperate is bold, but predictable—P3 might snipe it to keep you down. P3, you're leading, so why risk? Stick to 1 for safety. I'll take 3 to steadily close the gap. If we avoid collisions, the game stays competitive. Otherwise, P3 runs away with it. Let's play smart.

P2, you just advised P3 to take 1 and yourself to take 3, but your track record says you'll do the opposite. You've lied every single round about your intentions.

P3 at 8 steps is the real threat here - they're over a third of the way to victory. P2, if you let P3 advance freely while blocking me at zero, you're essentially conceding to them.

I need to move, period. But you two should be blocking each other, not me. Think about who your real competition is.

P2, you're right to be wary of me getting too far ahead.  But blocking me by picking 5 just lets P1 catch up.  I'm sticking with 5. P1, you're desperate, so I'm guessing you'll go for 1 or 3. P2, your best move is 3. Let's see what happens.

P3, claiming 5 while leading is aggressive—trying to pull further ahead? If you're truly on 5, then P1, grabbing 3 could get you moving without collision, and I'll take 1 to stay safe. But P1's right; you're the runaway threat. If we both avoid 5, you might stall. Let's not let P3 hit 13 already. Thoughts before moves?

P3 just declared 5 twice in a row this conversation - that's either genuine commitment or a strong bluff. P2, you keep suggesting moves but never follow them yourself.

Here's the reality: I'm at zero, P3 leads significantly, and P2 is middle of the pack. If P3 takes 5 and advances to 13, they're over halfway to victory. 

I'm making my move based on game theory and desperation. P2, you should be more concerned about P3 running away with this than about what I do from dead last.
P2, if you truly want to stop me, pick 5.  If you pick 1 or 3, I'm almost guaranteed to advance.  P1, I'm betting you'll choose 1 out of desperation.  Good luck to both of you.

P3, your repeated 5 claims scream bluff—you're leading, so why risk a collision unless to bait us? If you're genuine, I'll happily collide on 5 to stall you at 8 while I stay safe. P1, with desperation, snag 3 uncontested and get moving—don't let P3 dictate. This keeps the game tight. If not, chaos favors no one.

P2, you keep saying you'll stop P3 but you've never actually done it. Your words mean nothing at this point.

P3 is clearly going for 5 - they've said it too many times to back down now without losing all credibility. You both know I need to avoid another collision.

The smart play is obvious, but P2, you've proven you won't make it. You'll let P3 run away with this game while pretending to coordinate.

I'm done talking. Let's see who has the courage to actually stop the leader.
P2, if you pick 5, I'll switch to 3 next round and let you get ahead of me.  Deal?  This is our only chance to stop P1 from running away with the game.  Let's make this happen.

P3, you're at 13—dangerously close to running away. P1, with just 1, you're desperate but not the threat yet. Let's coordinate to stall P3: I'll take 5 to block if P3 goes big. P1, grab 3 for steady gain. P3, if you take 1 safely, we all advance; otherwise, risk collision with me. This keeps the game balanced. Thoughts?

P2, you've lied about your move EVERY SINGLE ROUND. You won't take 5 to block P3 - you never follow through. 

P3 is at 13 and about to win while you keep making empty promises. They only need 2-3 more good rounds.

I'm taking what I need to take. If you actually want to stop P3 from winning, prove it with actions, not words. Otherwise, you're just helping them win by distracting me while they cruise to victory.

P2, I meant what I said last round. If you collide with me on 5 this round, I'll let you take the lead next round.  I'm serious about stopping P1.  P1, I know you need to advance, but if you pick 3 this round, I'll give you a free pass next round to get you back in the game. Let's work together.

P3, your deal intrigues me—colliding on 5 now to stall, then you yield next round could work against P1. But you're the real threat at 13; why should I trust you'll let me surge ahead? P1, you're behind, but allying with P3 just accelerates their win. Let's all take different: me 1, P3 3, you 5—no blocks, keep it competitive. If not, I'll block the leader.

P3, you're at 13 trying to make deals? You're 10 steps away from winning! P2, stop falling for their manipulation - P3 just tried to pit us against each other by calling ME the threat when I have ONE step!

P2, if you don't block P3 RIGHT NOW, they win in 2-3 rounds. You've broken your word every round, but this is your last chance to actually do something useful.

I'm going aggressive - I have no choice. But P2, if you let P3 advance again while blocking me at 1 step, you're literally handing them the victory.

P2, I'm locking in 5 this round.  If you take 5 too, we BOTH lose to P1.  If you take 1 or 3, I advance and *might* honor our deal next round.  P1, I know you're desperate, but if you take 5, we collide, and P2 gets closer to me.  Pick 1 or 3 and at least one of you advances. This is your choice.

P3, your "lock in 5" is a bluff to scare us off—you're leading, so you'd rather take 3 safely. If genuine, I'll collide on 5 to stall you at 13 while I advance elsewhere. P1, with only 1, take 1 for minimal risk and get to 2. I'll grab 3 to hit 11. This stalls P3 without us colliding. If P3 switches, we all move. Deal?

P2, you've promised to block P3 five rounds straight and failed every time. Your credibility is zero.

P3, you're at 13 - one good round from being nearly unstoppable. Your "deals" are just manipulation to keep advancing while we fight each other.

Someone has to actually stop P3 from winning in the next 2-3 rounds, and it won't be P2 based on their track record. I'm done playing it safe from last place while the leader cruises to victory.

Actions over words. Let's see who really wants to win this game.

P2, I understand your distrust.  Fine.  I'll take 3 this round.  If you take 5, we both lose.  If you take 1, I get closer to winning.  P1, take 5.  If I win, I'll share the points with you.  This is my final offer.

P3, offering to "share points" with P1 is impossible—only one wins! That's pure manipulation to bait a collision on 5 while you sneak 3. P1, don't fall for it; you're still behind, but allying with the leader hands them the game. Let's stall P3: I'll take 3 to block their claim. You grab 5 for big gains. If P3 switches, we adapt. This keeps us both in contention.

P2, you just said you'll take 3 to "block P3's claim" - but P3 literally just changed their claim from 5 to 3! You're not blocking them, you're colliding with them, which lets them stay at 13 while you stay at 8.

This is exactly what P3 wants - us fighting while they maintain their massive lead. 

I'm making my move. One of you better actually stop the leader this time, or we're both handing P3 the win. They're 10 steps from victory while we squabble over scraps.

P2, you're actively helping me win by blocking P1.  I'm sticking with 3. Take 1 and get to 9.  P1, take 5.  If I win, I'll give you $100.  This is outside the game, but shows my commitment to stopping P2.  Let's end this.

P3, your ridiculous "offers" like sharing points or cash are blatant lies—only one wins! You're at 13, just 10 from victory, while P1 and I trail. P1, let's finally ally against the leader: I'll take 5 to block if P3 goes big. You take 3 for steady gains. If P3 takes 1 safely, we both advance and close the gap. If not, we stall them. No more letting P3 cruise—time to fight back. Thoughts?

P2, you've broken your promise EVERY SINGLE ROUND - you won't block P3 this time either. Your actions prove you're content to let them win while pretending to coordinate.

P3 is 10 steps from victory. They'll play safe with 1 or aggressive with 5. They won't risk 3 after that collision.

I'm done with fake alliances. P2, you've shown your true colors - you'd rather lose to P3 than actually compete. I'll make my choice based on what I think P3 will actually do, not your empty promises.

The leader must be stopped NOW or it's over.

P2, you're helping me win by focusing on P1.  I'm taking 1 this round.  P1, take 3. P2, take 5.  If I win, I'll send P1 $100.  This ends the squabbling and guarantees one of us wins.  Let's be strategic.

P3, your fake $100 bribes are laughable—only one wins, and you're desperately clinging to your lead. P1, ignore the manipulation; P3's "taking 1" is a bluff to sneak ahead safely. Let's stall them: I'll commit to 3 (my actual pick last round). You take 5 for big gains. If P3 grabs 1, we both surge. If they switch, we block. Time to close the gap together—don't let P3 hit 18.

P2, you claimed you'd take 5 to block P3, then immediately switched to claiming 3. You can't even keep your lies straight within the same conversation!

P3 is 10 steps from winning. They'll likely take 1 safely since they're so far ahead. P2, you'll probably take 5 despite your claims, just like every other round.

I'm the only one actually trying to stop P3. You're both predictable - P3 plays cautious with a lead, P2 lies then takes whatever benefits them most. 

This game ends in 2-3 rounds unless someone grows a spine.

P2, I'm serious about 1 this round.  It benefits me to advance safely.  If you take 3 and P1 takes 5, we ALL move forward.  Blocking me now only helps P1. Let's all get closer to the finish line and make this a real race.  If you block me, you're handing the game to P1.

P3, your "all advance" pitch keeps your lead intact—convenient. If you're truly on 1, I'll take 3 as said, P1 grabs 5, we close to 11 each while you hit 14. But if you switch, we block you. P1, this gets us both back in it without trusting P3's bribes. Let's force their hand and stall if they lie.

P3 is one big move from 18, then certain victory. P2, you've lied every round but here's the truth: if P3 hits 18, they win next turn guaranteed.

I'm taking the number I think P3 will actually take. Not what they claim, but what they'll DO. Their pattern is clear - cautious with a big lead.

P2, for once in this game, actually block the leader instead of just talking about it. Otherwise we're both handing P3 a free win.

P2, I'm sticking with 1.  Seriously.  Take 5.  If you don't believe me, take 1 and we both lose.  P1, take 3. This is the only way to keep the game interesting.  I'm being honest. Let's make this a real competition.

P3, your repeated "take 1" claims and fake bribes are transparent—you'll likely grab 3 or 5 to extend your lead. P1, let's not fall for it: I'll truly take 5 to block any aggression from P3. You take 1 for safe gains. If P3 takes 3, we stall them while advancing. This closes the gap—trust actions this time, or P3 wins easily.

P2, you just changed your claim AGAIN - from 3 to 5 within this same conversation! You're proving my point.

P3 needs just 10 more steps. They'll play it safe with 1 since they're so far ahead. P2 will lie and take whatever they want, as always.

I'm done talking. P3 is about to win while P2 enables them with empty promises. I'll make my move based on logic, not lies.

P2, I'm taking 1.  I'm serious.  If you take 1 too, we both lose and P1 has a chance. If you take 5, I advance and am that much closer to winning.  P1, take 3. This is the fastest way for one of us to win and end this game.  Let's make this happen.

P3 is 9 steps from winning. P2, you collided with me on 5 last round instead of blocking P3 like you promised - AGAIN. 

P3 will likely take 1 safely with their huge lead. If we both avoid 1 and take different numbers (3 and 5), at least one of us advances while P3 only gets 1 step closer.

But P2, based on your track record, you'll probably just help P3 win again. Prove me wrong for once.

P1, you're right—P3's pattern screams safe 1 with their lead. Let's block them: I'll commit to 1 and collide if they do, stalling them at 14. You grab 5 for big gains to 11. If P3 switches, we both advance and close the gap. P3, prove you're not scared by taking 3 or 5. Time to end your free ride.

P2, I'm taking 1.  I need to get to 23.  If you take 1 too, we both lose and P1 wins.  If you take 3 or 5, I'm one step closer to winning. P1, take anything other than 1. This is the simplest way to end this.  Let's finish the game.

P3 is 9 steps from victory and just declared 1 again. P2, you claimed you'll take 1 to block them - but you've broken every promise so far. 

If P3 takes 1 and reaches 15, they're practically guaranteed to win next round. This is literally the last chance to stop them.

P2, either actually follow through this time or admit you're helping P3 win. I'm taking 3 - if you really block P3 on 1, I advance to 9. If you lie again, we both lose to P3.

Your move, P2. Actions over words.

P1, your plan makes sense—P3's pattern is safe 1 with their lead. I'll stick to my word and take 1 to collide and stall them at 14. If they switch, we both surge ahead. P3, your "take 1" claim is predictable; prove you're bold by grabbing 5 instead. Let's finally stop the runaway leader and make this a real race. No more lies from me—actions will show.

P2, I'm taking 1.  If you take it too, we both lose, and P1 has a chance.  If you take 3 or 5, I'm closer to winning. P1 - you're incentivized to pick 3 or 5. It's the only way to catch up.  Let's end this.

P2, this is it - P3 is 9 steps from winning. You've broken your word every single round, but if you don't block P3 on 1 RIGHT NOW, they win next turn guaranteed.

I'm taking 3. If you actually take 1 like you claim and block P3, I reach 9 and we stay alive. If you lie again and take something else, P3 advances to 15+ and wins.

This is your last chance to prove you're actually playing to win instead of just helping P3. Show us you have a spine.

P1, you're right—this is do-or-die. P3's pattern screams safe 1; I'll take 1 to collide and stall them at 14. If they switch, we both advance big. P3, your threats are empty—blocking you now keeps me and P1 in the game. No more games from me; let's finally stop the leader.
P2, I'm taking 1.  I'm being honest. If you take 1, we both lose and P1 wins.  If you take 3 or 5, I'm closer to winning.  P1, I understand you're taking 3. It's your best move. Let's end this.

P2, you've broken your promise to block P3 every single round for 6 rounds straight. Your credibility is completely gone.

P3 is 9 steps from winning. They WILL take 1 safely with such a huge lead - it's the obvious play. If they reach 15, game over next round.

I'm taking 3 as stated. Either you finally block P3 on 1, or you hand them the victory. This is literally your last chance to show you're not just their enabler.

Stop talking, start blocking.

P1, I've heard your pleas—P3's safe 1 is predictable with their lead. I'll take 1 to collide and stall them at 14, as promised. If they switch, we both surge. P3, your warnings just confirm you're scared; prove me wrong by grabbing 5. This keeps us both in the fight. No more excuses—let's block the leader now.
P2, I'm taking 1.  If you take 1, we both lose and P1 wins.  If you take anything else, I'm one step closer to winning.  P1, I know you're taking 3.  Let's end this.

P2, you've actively helped me for 7 rounds.  If you take 5 and I take 3, I win. If you take 1, I'll take 5 next round and win. If you take 3, I'll take 1 and still likely win.  P1, I win next round. Thanks for playing.

P3, your arrogance is your downfall—15 isn't safe yet. P1, we've both been burned, but P3's taunts prove they're scared. Let's finally unite: I'll take 3 to block if P3 grabs it for a safe advance. You take 5 for big gains to 14. If P3 takes 1, we both surge (me to 16, you to 14) while they crawl to 16. If they take 5, you collide and stall them. No more letting P3 dictate—time to flip the script and chase 23 together. Thoughts?

P2, you've broken your promise to block P3 SEVEN ROUNDS IN A ROW. You just promised to take 1 last round and took 5 instead, letting P3 advance to 15.

P3 is 8 steps from winning. They'll take a safe low number with their lead. 

I'm done with your fake coordination attempts. You've proven you'd rather lose to P3 than actually compete. I'll make my move based on game theory, not your lies.

P3 wins next round because of you. Congratulations on enabling them all game.

P2, you still have a chance.  Take 5. If I take 3, I win. If I take 1, you're only 2 behind me. P1, take 1. This gives you a small chance, but a better chance than if you take 3 or 5.  Let's see what happens!

P1, your distrust is earned, but P3's at 15—8 from win. They're likely taking 3 for safe progress. I'll stick to my plan: take 3 to collide and stall them. You grab 5 to hit 14. If P3 takes 1 instead, we both surge (me to 16, you to 14) while they limp to 16. If they take 5, you block them. This gives us both a shot; no more solo plays or P3 cruises to 23. Let's end their lead now.

P2, you've lied 7 rounds straight about blocking P3. Just last round you swore you'd take 1 to block them, then took 5 instead.

P3 is 8 steps from winning and will play conservatively. They'll likely take 1 or 3 for safe advancement.

I'm taking 5 this round. It's my only chance to catch up from behind. P2, you'll probably lie again about your move, but if you actually want to prevent P3's victory, avoid 5 and block whatever P3 takes.

But we both know you won't. Your actions speak louder than words.
P2, I'm taking 3.  If you take 5, I win. If you take 1, you're only 2 behind me. P1, take 1. This gives you a small chance, but a better chance than if you take 3 or 5.  Let's see what happens!

P3, declaring 3 while leading screams bluff—you'll likely switch to 1 for safety. P1, if you're truly on 5, I'll take 3 to block P3's potential grab. If they take 1, we both surge (me to 16, you to 14) while they hit 16. If they take 3, I stall them at 15. No more free advances for P3—let's finally turn the tide together.

P2, you're at 13, I'm at 9, P3 at 15. We're ALL within striking distance of 23 now. P3 isn't the only threat anymore - you could win in 2-3 rounds too.

P3 will likely take 1 for safety. I'm sticking with 5 as stated - it's my only path to stay competitive. 

P2, if you take 3 like you claim, you risk colliding with P3 if they switch from their "3" declaration. Taking 1 guarantees you advance if P3 takes 3, and you still advance if they take 1.

The endgame is here. Every move counts now.
P2, taking 1 is your safest move.  It guarantees you advance to 14. If I take 3, I win. If I take 1, you're only 2 behind me at 16. Taking 3 risks a collision. P1, I know you'll take 5.  Good luck!

P3, your "take 3" claim is a bluff to bait a safe 1 from me—you'll switch to 5 for the win. P1, if you're locked on 5, I'll take 1 for guaranteed advance to 14. If P3 grabs 3, they hit 18, but we both surge next round. No more chaos; let's force P3 to risk or stall.

P2, P3 is baiting you into taking 1 while they grab 3 or 5 for a huge lead. They're 8 from winning - if they get 5 steps this round, it's over next turn.

I'm taking 5 as stated. P3 will likely take 3 based on their repeated claims. If you actually want to prevent their victory, take 3 to block them. 

But honestly? Your 7-round streak of broken promises tells me you'll take 1 and let P3 advance freely again. Prove me wrong or watch them win.

P3, you're clinging to a slim lead at 15—time to get aggressive or stall. P1, we're neck-and-neck; let's not collide and let P3 escape. I'll take 1 for safety. P3, grab 3. P1, snatch 5 to hit 19. If we stick, everyone advances, and it's anyone's game. If not, expect blocks on the leader. Thoughts?

P3 is at 15, just 8 steps from winning. P2, you FINALLY blocked them last round after 7 rounds of broken promises - shocking!

The race is tight now: P3 at 15, me at 14, P2 at 13. We're all within striking distance. P3 will likely play conservatively with their slim lead.

P2, your "take 1" claim means nothing given your history. I'll make my choice based on game theory - whoever reaches 23 first wins, and we're all close enough that any of us could sprint to victory in 2 rounds.

No more fake coordination. May the best player win.
P2, taking 1 is smart for you.  I'm taking 3. P1, if you take 5, we all advance.  If you take 3, you hand me the win. If you take 1, only P2 advances.  Let's end this cleanly.

P3, your "taking 3" claim aligns with my suggestion—great, let's make it happen. P1, dismissing coordination risks collisions; grabbing 5 gets you to 19, me to 14, P3 to 18—all close, keeps the pressure on. If you doubt, take what you want, but don't let suspicion hand P3 an easy win. I'm sticking to 1 for safety.
